context: Act 2A Chapter 2.1 — Late night hotel bar. Jade drops the corporate mask. Her background, dreams, compromises. Real connection forming.

lines.text: The Apex Grand Hotel. Twenty-second floor bar. The kind of place where the drinks don't have prices on the menu because if you have to ask, you can't afford to be here.

It is 1:47 AM. The bar is empty except for the bartender, a jazz pianist playing for nobody, and Jade Winters sitting at the far end with a glass of whiskey and her shoes on the floor beside her stool.
Without her heels, she is shorter than you expected. Without her corporate armor — the blazer draped over the next stool, the collar loosened — she looks younger. More human. Less weapon.

lines.speaker: Jade
lines.text: Couldn't sleep either?
She gestures to the stool beside her. There is already a drink waiting.

lines.speaker: Jade
lines.text: I ordered you one when I saw you in the elevator lobby. Call it manager's intuition.

choices.text: How did you know I'd come down?
You look different without the armor.

lines.label: jade_knows
lines.speaker: Jade
lines.text: Because you're the kind of person who doesn't sleep after their first real race. The adrenaline doesn't know where to go when the engine stops. I remember the feeling.
She takes a sip of whiskey. Her eyes are distant — focused on something between the glass and the window.

lines.label: jade_armor
lines.text: Something crosses her face. Not offense — surprise. Like no one has said that to her in a very long time.

lines.speaker: Jade
lines.text: The armor weighs about forty pounds. Figuratively. You'd be amazed how heavy a smile can be when you've been wearing it for twelve hours.

lines.label: jade_long_day
lines.speaker: Jade
lines.text: Long day. Long year. Long career.
She swirls the whiskey. The ice clinks against the glass. It is a lonely sound.

lines.label: jade_opens_up
lines.text: Silence. Comfortable silence, the kind that only exists between people who both know what it feels like to push a car past what it should be capable of.

lines.speaker: Jade
lines.text: I didn't always work for Apex.
She says it quietly. Like she is testing the words — seeing if they still sound true.

lines.speaker: Jade
lines.text: I used to race. Did you know that? I was good, too. Not great — I didn't have the thing you have, that ability to feel the car like it's part of your body. But I was smart. Strategic.

lines.speaker: Jade
lines.text: I started in endurance racing. Semi-pro, weekend events, sleeping in the back of my car between stages. For three years, I was happy. Broke, but happy.

lines.speaker: Jade
lines.text: Then Apex approached me. Not to drive — to manage. They saw something in the way I analyzed races, the way I understood the business side. They offered me a salary that made my driving income look like pocket change.

lines.speaker: Jade
lines.text: I said no. Three times. I was a driver. That's who I was.
She finishes the whiskey. Sets the glass down. Does not order another.

lines.speaker: Jade
lines.text: The fourth time, they offered me enough to pay off my mother's medical debt. All of it. In one contract.
She looks at the empty glass.

lines.speaker: Jade
lines.text: I haven't been behind a wheel in seven years. Sometimes I dream about it. The engine note, the G-force in the corners, the way the world narrows to just the road and the car and the next apex.

lines.speaker: Jade
lines.text: Then I wake up in a hotel room and check my email and the dream evaporates. Like exhaust.

choices.text: You gave up your dream to save your mother. That's not a compromise — that's love.
It's not too late. You could still race.

lines.label: jade_moved
lines.text: Jade goes very still. Her hand on the bar tightens. For a moment, you think she might cry. She doesn't — she's had too much practice not crying — but the effort is visible.

lines.speaker: Jade
lines.text: Nobody's ever described it that way before. Most people say I made the smart choice.

lines.speaker: Jade
lines.text: Smart. Like love is a calculation.

lines.label: jade_regret_answer
lines.speaker: Jade
lines.text: Every single day.
She says it without hesitation. The fastest answer she has given all night.

lines.speaker: Jade
lines.text: And every single day, I know I'd do it again. That's the worst part — not the regret. The certainty.

lines.label: jade_still_race_response
lines.speaker: Jade
lines.text: You sound like me at twenty-five. Full of the belief that wanting something is enough to make it possible.

lines.speaker: Jade
lines.text: But you know what? Maybe that's why I recruited you. Not because you're the fastest — though you might be. Because you still believe the dream is the destination. I need to be around that. Even if I can't feel it myself anymore.

lines.label: jade_closing
lines.text: The pianist finishes his set. The last note hangs in the air like smoke.

lines.speaker: Jade
lines.text: I don't usually talk like this. The whiskey, the hour, the — I don't know. Something about you makes me forget the script.

lines.speaker: Jade
lines.text: Don't tell anyone I said any of this. I have a reputation to maintain.
She puts her shoes back on. The two inches of heel restore the Jade you met on Media Day — the corporate weapon, the brand manager, the woman who controls rooms with a glance.
But now you know who's underneath. And that changes everything.

lines.speaker: Jade
lines.text: Early start tomorrow. Get some sleep.
She walks to the elevator. Pauses.

lines.speaker: Jade
lines.text: Thank you. For listening. Most people in this world don't listen — they just wait for their turn to talk.
The elevator doors close. You sit alone at the bar, watching the city lights through the window. Nova Pacifica at night, from twenty-two floors up, looks like a circuit board.
Somewhere down there, Maya is closing the garage. Diesel is nursing a drink in a bar that doesn't have a jazz pianist. The Pit is coming alive.
And up here, a woman who gave up her dream to save someone she loved just showed you the crack in her armor.
You finish your drink and take the stairs. The elevator feels too easy.
